# Draft:TrackingTime

----
}}
TrackingTime is a time tracking and work-management platform developed by the Argentina-based company of the same name. Available on web, desktop, and mobile, it allows users to record working hours, organize tasks, and generate billing or payroll reports. The software is used internationally by distributed and hybrid teams.
History
Founding and development
TrackingTime was founded in 2012 by Eric Tulle, Leonardo Custer, and Diego Wyllie in Buenos Aires, Argentina.
The application was initially designed for freelancers and small agencies before expanding to support larger teams and company-wide workflows.
Product evolution
In 2020, the company released a redesigned interface intended to simplify navigation and onboarding for remote teams.
In 2023, TrackingTime introduced modular features such as attendance, time-off, and budgeting options.
In 2025, Digital Journal reported that the company changed its pricing model to provide its full time-tracking functionality free for unlimited users, describing the move as “a radical bet on accessibility” aimed at supporting small-business scalability.
Reception
In 2025, Mashable Netherlands described TrackingTime as a tool that promotes trust-based productivity and distances itself from surveillance-driven management approaches.
Business Insider noted the platform’s expansion to serve organizations “from startup stage to enterprise scale,” citing its tiered pricing and tools for operational visibility.
TechTimes listed TrackingTime among the “Top 5 Best Time Tracking Software of 2025,” and described it as suitable for both startups and larger teams.
A follow-up TechTimes review discussed adoption among agencies and remote teams.
Forbes Advisor included the product in its “10 Best Time Tracking Software of 2024” feature, and FinancesOnline rated it positively for affordability and functionality.
Additional coverage and comparative reviews appear on Jibble, Software Finder and Research.com, which have evaluated the platform’s usability and functionality in relation to other time-tracking tools.
User-review platforms such as G2, Capterra, and Software Advice report average ratings around 4.5 out of 5 for reliability and customer support.

Notes for reviewers
This revision responds directly to reviewer feedback from 5 November 2025 by:
* Emphasizing **independent, reliable secondary sources** (Digital Journal, Mashable Netherlands, Business Insider, TechTimes, Forbes Advisor, FinancesOnline).
* Removing promotional language and using strictly neutral, attributed phrasing.
* Adding verifiable evidence of corporate notability (2025 pricing change independently reported by Digital Journal).
* Retaining comparative and user-review citations only as supplementary context.
* Maintaining encyclopedic tone and structure consistent with accepted SaaS articles such as Toggl, Clockify, and Asana.
